=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐language breakdown:

• Game Genre and Feel 
 This is a top‐down action–puzzle game. It mixes arcade shooting (your avatar fires sword projectiles) with puzzle-like manipulation of characters and objects in a maze-like level.

• Mechanics and How Things Work
 – The level is laid out in a grid with walls, floors, and various interactive objects.
 – You control the avatar (a shooter) that can fire a “sword” projectile.
 – There are several NPCs: one type is a “nokey” swordman who, if he touches a key, transforms into a “withkey” version (this transformation scores points).
 – The key and the goal (a door, colored green) are special items. The goal is “opened” (or removed) when a withkey character touches it, scoring a point.
 – There are also roaming monsters with different speeds (quick, normal, slow) that move at random and can harm your avatar.
 – Collisions are handled with simple rules. For example, if the avatar touches an enemy, the enemy is killed but you lose points (and possibly risk death). In contrast, using your sword projectile against an enemy gives you extra points.
 – There are “stepBack” interactions as well so that moving objects (or characters) might be pushed back if they bump into something immovable like a wall.

• Objectives, Win, and Loss Conditions
 – The overall objective is to “open the door” by having a withkey (the transformed swordman) reach the goal sprite. When the goal is removed (i.e. after a correct collision) the game is won.
 – You lose if your avatar is eliminated. So staying safe from the roaming monsters and from hazardous collisions is essential.

• Overall Strategy
 – First, consider how to get the key into play: Encourage or allow a nokey sprite to come into contact with the key so it transforms into a withkey sprite.
 – Then, clear a safe path for that withkey character to reach the door (the goal) without interference from monsters.
 – Use your shooting ability to eliminate enemies that might block the path or threaten your avatar—remember that shooting enemies scores points.
 – Keep an eye on the different roaming monsters: Their speeds and random paths mean timing is important. Avoid close encounters, as colliding with an enemy in your avatar form can be costly.
 – In summary, manage the environment by balancing offense (using your sword projectile on dangerous enemies) with indirect puzzle solving (helping a non-player character get the key and deliver it to the door).

This mix of careful positioning, timely shooting, and indirect puzzle management is at the heart of the game’s challenge and strategy. Enjoy the mix of action and brain work!

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.
